title: How can life come from non-life without intelligent intervention? - Quora

response.answer_text: The most basic fact about physical and chemical reactions is that, when conditions are ‘right’, those reactions necessarily take place. They have no choice but to react when the ingredients and conditions facilitate the reaction. OK. The reactions automatically take place under the right conditions. The Earth offered infinite locations where the ingredients were present and the conditions favorable, so the inanimate chemicals did what they had to do and reaced with one another. Out of this infinity of reactions, some were of the type that eventually led to the formation of large molecules that had the power to self-replicate. You have to remember three things: 1. these reactions had to happen,I 2. the world is a very large place with an infinity of opportunities for reactions to occur and 3. these reactions happened every day for millions of years. There was plenty of time for the right sequence of reactions to convert inanimate chemical elements into the larger forms that we call living. The process of life arising from inert chemicals was, given the right conditions, enough places and enough time, absolutely inevitable. There is no reason to invoke an imaginary supernatural entity (which is a terrible way to explain anything) in this natural but slow process.

Sugars and phosphates can form ribonucleotides if they are repeatedly heated and cooled, such as around volcanic vents in the ocean.Ribonucleotides can chain up into RNA in the presence of some types of clay.RNA can be effective self-replicators, and can evolve to become better self-replicators.RNA can become encapsulated in a lipid bilayer bubble, and then you have a “cell” with an evolving genome.RNA can turn itself into DNA. (Not that this is needed in order for it to be “life”.) Once you have a cell with an evolving genome, the rest can happen through evolution, and things like endosymbiosis. That’s how life can begin. Did it being this way on Earth, 4-ish billion years ago? No one knows, but it sure is possible. It’s going to be hard to settle this question, since we don’t really expect there to still be evidence left of 4 billion years old chemical reactions. But maybe, somehow, or through some other line of evidence.

This is a great question. Almost every choice you make in your life depends on what you think the right answer is. There are three options, with three interesting problems: Random If you believe this you have to accept that inanimate matter can produce consciousness. This is called the hard problem in academic circles: David Chalmers Thinks the Hard Problem Is Really Hard The case for morality also becomes one of pure practicality. You only need to be careful about the things you think other people might see and react to, because your consciousness ceases to exist when your body does. God If God created life then you have to wrestle with the problem of how someone who loves you created the suffering we see in the world (and no, it’s not a fair test). This is a well known problem and is called theodicy. If this is your world view you need to be careful about every thing you do, even the stuff you might get away with during this life time, because he’s watching. You will also be tempted to blame God when things go wrong, and hope that they will forgive you. Cause and Effect This view sees consciousness as being distinct from a physical body. It is based on the idea that everything comes from something similar prior to it, so consciousness would come from a previous moment of consciousness. The mind is the primary driver for what you experience. The problem here is that you have to accept that there is no first cause, consciousness would extend back infinitely in time. It is a world view associated with Buddhists and Hindus. The case for morality here is exactly the same as in the Christian world view — you need to be careful about everything you think, say, or do because you are carrying your actions in your mind stream and they will affect how you perceive the world at some future date. But it is all on you to create what you want for your future. I hope this helps. Let me know what your thoughts are!

Random chance. We know that there are organic molecules in the Universe. If you take a soup of non-living organic molecules and hit it with lightning, you eventually get amino acid, a building block of life. The theory is that if you do this over the whole planet for billions of years, you get some genetic material, and then life evolves. That’s a pretty sloppy formulation of the theory. The random connection of some atoms into molecules that catalyze the creation of copies of themselves is the start of life. There are two theories of how this may have happen that go by the short hand terms: metabolism-first and replication-first. There’s a good book on the metabolism-first theory “The Vital Question” by Nick Lane and also a good lecture to the Royal Society by him on Youtube. There’s also a good series of online lectures on the RNA theory by Jack Szostak of Harvard.
